title-group.article-title: Reliability and Safety Assessments of the Satellite Separation Process of a Typical Launch Vehicle

article-meta.aff: 1LVM3 Project, Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre, India
2RLV-TD Project, Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre, India
3Structural Analysis and Testing Group, Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre, India

author-notes.corresp: B Nageswara Rao, Structural Analysis and Testing Group, Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre, Thiruvananthapuram-695022, India. Email: bnrao52@rediffmail.com; b_nageswararao@vssc.gov.in

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: USMOS Conference: Recent Research on Defence M&S in Turkey

abstract.p: This paper presents in brief the formulation of the rigid body separation dynamics that are useful for the design and analysis of satellite separation systems using the helical compression spring mechanism. In satellite launch vehicle chronology, safe injection of the satellite into the desirable orbit is an important final task. The body rate of the satellite during separation should be within the satellite control capabilities. The Taguchi method is employed in order to understand the influencing parameters in the separation process. Statistical analysis has been carried out to identify the probability distribution function for reliability and safety assessment of the satellite separation of a launch vehicle. Using the response surface method (RSM), an empirical relation is obtained for the body rate of the satellite in terms of the 28 physical parameters. The RSM results are compared with the Taguchi simulation results. Reliability and safety assessments are made on the satellite separation of a typical launch vehicle.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: A typical launch mission may involve several separation events, such as the stage separation, the strapon separation, the heat shield separation, and the satellite separation.1 Safe injection of satellite into the desirable orbit is an important task in a satellite launch vehicle chronology. During satellite separation, the body rate of the satellite should be within the satellite control system capabilities. A higher body rate may cause tumbling and reduction in the life of the satellite. Faulty separation systems were suspected to be the main culprits in the launch failures of Atlas Centaur in 1970 and the Chinese Long March in 1992 and improper placing of satellite orbits in the launch failures of Titan in 1990, Pegasus in 1991, and Delta-2 in 1995. With the advancement of satellite technologies, it is restrictive to demand a near zero lateral center of mass of the satellite and, despite all efforts, modern satellites do inherently possess nominal lateral center of mass offsets, which are large. These offsets impart undesirable, as well as unacceptable, lateral body rates on the satellite. One attractive way to reduce this rate is to have springs of different energy levels employed within the same separation system. The separation mechanism consists of a band, comprising a bolt cutter on either side of the satellite at the vehicle payload adaptor interface. The separation velocity is imparted by a set of pre-compressed springs. Springs, the bolt cutter, and band segments are retained with the spent stage. Upper stage residual thrust is normally ensured to be near zero during separation. Usually, the upper stage is either a liquid stage or a cryo-stage. Hence, force due to passivation or evaporation/venting of residual fuel exists. In addition, there are various projections located either on the satellite or on the upper stage that need to be monitored for non-interference. Many times, the satellite’s liquid apogee motor would have protrusion due to antenna and mounting brackets. Collision-free separation should be ensured in the presence of all of these projections, even in the worst combination of all the sensitive parameters. The dynamics of separating bodies has received the attention of several investigators.2–8

This paper utilizes the Taguchi method for reliability and safety assessments on the satellite separation process of a typical launch vehicle, shown in Figure 1. This approach identifies factors contributing to the variation in the system performance and also the sensitivity of each parameter. Statistical analyses are performed for the construction of the probability distribution function (PDF), which is useful in the reliability and safety assessments. Using the response surface method (RSM), an empirical relation is obtained for the satellite body rate in terms of the 28 physical parameters. The RSM results are compared with those obtained from Taguchi’s design of experiments.

caption.p: Typical launch vehicle showing the strapon, core-stage, and satellite separation planes.

sec.title: 2. Methodology and formulation
sec.p: Rao et al.7 have presented the mathematical formulation for rigid body separation dynamics, which is useful for space launch vehicles. The physical problem is to simulate the dynamic characteristics of the separating rigid bodies under the influence of forces and moments acting on them. Each individual body has three velocity components, three components of position vector, three body rates, and three attitude angles. In principle, equations of motion can be solved in any co-ordinate system. It is preferable to solve them in the body co-ordinate system, as the moment of inertia, engine tail off thrust, and aerodynamic computations are very simple in the body co-ordinate system. Figures 2 and 3 show the different co-ordinate frames used in the present study. The XI, YI, and ZI axes, as shown in the Figure 2, define the Earth-centered inertial (ECI) co-ordinate system. The axes XI and YI lie in the equatorial plane and ZI points towards the North Pole. Gravitational forces are computed in this co-ordinate system. The XT, YT, and ZT axes define the topocentric or launch point inertial (LPI) co-ordinate system. The ECI and LPI co-ordinates are related through the launch azimuth (Az), launch site geocentric latitude (ФGC), and launch site longitude (Θ). The vehicle orientation at any time is defined with the Euler angles, viz., yaw attitude angle (ψ), pitch attitude angle (θ), and roll attitude angle (φ) with respect to the LPI frame. The body frame coincides with the LPI frame at the time of launch. It has its origin at the center of gravity (CG) of the individual bodies, namely the main (ongoing) body and the separating (spent) body, as shown in the Figure 3. The XM, YM, and ZM axes with MCG as the origin define the main body co-ordinate system. The XS, YS, and ZS axes with SCG as the origin define the separating body co-ordinate system. The XL, YL, and ZL axes coincide with the body axes of the combined body just before separation. This frame moves with a constant velocity that is the same as that of the combined body at the instant of separation. Figure 4 shows the oblate Earth geometry. The oblate Earth’s model defined by the gravitational constant (µ), equatorial radius (RE), polar radius (Rp), J2 harmonic and higher order gravitational harmonics (J3 and J4) are considered for the Earth model. The Earth model computes the gravitational acceleration along ECI frame and transforms to the body frame where computation of body dynamics takes place.

caption.p: Earth-centered inertial (ECI) and launch point inertial (LPI) frames.
Common body inertial (CBI) and local inertial co-ordinate systems.

Here Ixx, Iyy, and Izz are the principal moment of inertia about yaw, pitch, and roll (X, Y, Z) axes, respectively. Ixy, Ixz, Iyx, Iyz, Izx, and Izy are the product of inertia with respect to the indicated planes, for example, xy, xz, yz. The symmetry in the products of inertia has been noted. It may be noted that the principal moments of inertia may only be positive, but the products of inertia may be either positive or negative.
Equations (1) and (2) can be written in the form
The kinematic differential equations, which provide the relationship between Euler angles and angular velocity components (body rates) are

Equations (4)–(6) are the governing equations of motion for the individual bodies undergoing separation. These are non-linear ordinary differential equations. These equations are to be solved numerically after specifying the components of total external force and moment vectors. The dynamic characteristics of the separating bodies are examined under the influence of the gravity and the spring forces and moments.

sec.title: 2.3 Force and moment of helical compression springs
sec.p: The motion of a satellite separating from its final stage of the launch vehicle by the force of helical compression springs is considered. The separation impulse is provided by release of the energy stored in the helical compression springs. The Z component of the spring mounting location in each body is computed as follows (see Figure 5): ZM = LMCG – MAXIAL and ZS = LMCG – SAXIAL. The radial components of spring mounting along the X and Y axes are rS cosδ and –rS sinδ. The spring force and moment are

sec.title: 2.4 Separation dynamic analysis
sec.p: For separation dynamic analysis, it is necessary to simulate the trajectories of separating bodies, taking into account the forces and moments acting on them. Using Equations (12)–(15), the total external force and moment vectors in equations of motion Equations (1) and (2) are written as

The solution of equations of motion will give the dynamic characteristics of the individual bodies undergoing separation. Critical points are identified on the separating bodies to estimate the clearances between them. For the identification of collision hazards during separation, the relative distance between the critical points, relative velocity, body angular velocity, and body orientation angles are estimated. The trace of the points together with body orientation angles confirm collision-free separation and build up of any tip-off errors on the ongoing functional stage. Graphical simulation of the separating bodies will also show the occurrence of collision (if any) during separation.

After determining the velocities of the individual bodies at a time ‘t’, the relative velocity between the separating bodies in the body frame is calculated. Applying the inverse transformation to the relative velocity and integrating with respect to time, the actual separation distance between the bodies is found. The magnitude of the body rate is
The relative velocity (vR) of the separating bodies is
The relative distance (dR) from the CGs, (or) the points identified at the separation plane of the separating bodies, is

Here (vx1, vy1, vz1), (x1, y1, zv), (vx2, vy2, vz2), and (x2, y2, z2) are the components of the velocity vector and position vector of the ongoing and spent body in the CBI frame. The integration of the equations of motion is continued until the spring relaxation time reaches one quarter of the period.

The problem is sufficiently large and complex. The methodology involves iteration at successively lower levels of abstraction. The object-oriented programming approach is applied for the development of the separation dynamic simulator.7 The object-oriented analysis is preferred to identify the various classes and objects to generate the required forces and moments of the separating bodies. The various classes identified are class Earth, class aerodynamics, class engines, and class systems. Class spring and class vented are the inherited (derived) class of the parent class ‘class systems’. Inheritance is the process whereby one object acquires (gets or receives) characteristics from one or more other objects. Similarly, class retro-rocket/ullage rocket is a derived class of the class engines. The class Earth provides the necessary information related to gravity, atmosphere, and wind. Class aerodynamics contains aerodynamic coefficients of the separating bodies and the member functions. Class engines deals with thrust-related data at the time of separation. Class architecture of the software thus obtained, shown in Figure 6, is central to the structure of the program. Appropriate objects were identified in the solution space to establish their relationship. Modern versatile programming language C++ is used to design this software through the VC++ developer studio. Fundamental capabilities are provided via C++, the most widely used object-oriented programming language.

sec.title: 3. Numerical simulations
sec.p: The design of any engineering system is a process of decision making under constraints of uncertainty. The uncertainty in the design process is due to lack of deterministic knowledge of different physical parameters with which the design is performed. The separation system design process depends on many parameters. Three common methods of evaluating the product’s response resulting from the variations in many factors are Monte Carlo simulation, multivariate, and orthogonal array-based simulation.7,8 The design of experiments using the Taguchi method9,10 seems to be more efficient compared to the Monte Carlo simulation. It can be utilized to arrive at the best parameters for the near optimum design configuration with the least number of analytical investigations.

Numerical analysis has been carried out to estimate the tip-off rates for the final stage of a typical advance multi-stage launch vehicle of geosynchronous transfer orbit. The trajectory parameters at the time of separation considered in the present study are:6 time of separation, t = 1175 seconds; altitude of separation, h = 235 km; ECI position, XI = −5.04096 E + 06 m, YI = 4.2639E + 06 m, ZI = −3.68485E + 05 m; initial body rate, r = −0.0244915 deg/s, q = 0.0863901 deg/s, p = −0.00900853 deg/s; initial attitude, ψ0 = 1.06252 deg, θ0 = 142.173 deg, φ0 = −0.0716475 deg. Table 1 gives the dynamic parameters of Jeyakumar and Biswas6 for the separating bodies at the time of separation. A fourth-order Runge–Kutta integration scheme is used to solve the non-linear ordinary differential equations with a fixed step size. To simplify the integration process, the time variable in the differential equations is normalized with the spring relaxation time of one quarter of the period. The components of ‘I ’ in Equation (3) are normalized by taking the maximum value of the components as a common factor.

caption.p: Input parameters for the separating bodies using the Taguchi method.

sec.p: Before selecting an orthogonal array (OA), the minimum number of simulations to be carried out is NTaguchi = 1 + Number of factors × DOF. An L81 OA is created by Latin squares from the computer program.8 Once the OA is selected, the experiments are conducted as per the level combinations. The performance parameter (output) is noted down for each experimental run for analysis. Since each experiment is the combination of different factor levels, it is essential to segregate the individual effect of independent variables. This is usually done by summing up the performance parameter values for corresponding level setting and then the mean is found. Then sum of the squares of deviation of each mean value from grand mean value is calculated. The sum of the squares of deviation of a particular variable indicates whether the performance parameter is sensitive to the change of level of setting.

Figure 7 shows the graphical simulation of satellite separation of a typical launch vehicle. The percentage contribution of the all the individual input parameters with respect to the output parameter, namely the ongoing body rate, is evaluated and depicted in Figure 8.

caption.p: Graphical simulation of the satellite separation of a typical launch vehicle.
Sensitivity of each input parameter with ongoing body rate.

sec.p: Figure 9 shows the plots of the ongoing body rate with the levels for each parameter. The level corresponding to higher body rate and lower body rate is selected for all the 28 parameters. Two more simulations are performed with these parameters for obtaining the maximum body rate and minimum body rate (worst case extreme values). The minimum body rate has no impact and it is of no concern. The maximum body rate (worst case) is obtained when Z13-Z22-Z33-Z41-Z53-Z63-Z71-Z83-Z93-Z103-Z112-Z123-Z133-Z142-Z153-Z163-Z172-Z182-Z192-Z202-Z212-Z222-Z231-Z241-Z252-Z262-Z273-Z283, where Z1, Z2, etc. are the 28 input parameters and the subscript denotes the level of the parameter (see Table 1).

caption.p: Plots of body rate with three levels of the physical parameters.

sec.p: Using the RSM, empirical relations are obtained for the body rate in terms of the 28 parameters. Equation (21) represents a linear variation:
All the constants in Equation (21) are given in Table 2. The nominal body rate obtained from the RSM relation is compared with the Taguchi’s design of experiments in Table 3:

caption.p: Constants of the response surface method (Equation (21)).
Comparison of response surface method (RSM) results with those obtained from Taguchi’s design of experiment.

tr.td: All parameters set in upper limit
All parameters set in lower limit

sec.p: The results of Equation (21) are found to be within ±4% of the Taguchi simulations. The standard error in Equation (21) with respect to the Taguchi simulations is 0.011.

sec.title: 4. Statistical analysis
sec.p: Based on the Taguchi simulation run, variation in the output response parameters, namely the body rate of the ongoing stage, relative velocity, and relative distance, obtained from the Taguchi OA are analyzed to determine the type of distribution they represent. One should note that the ongoing body rate and relative distance between the separating bodies fit to beta distribution, while the relative velocity fits to normal distribution. Figure 10 shows the histograms and individual frequency plots for identification of the PDF. Table 4 depicts the PDF constants, mean, percentage, and coefficient of variation (cov). The goodness-of-fit measures with chi-square (χ2) are also provided in Table 4. The chi-square (χ2) values for all the cases are found to be less than the critical values of test statistics at 5% significance level.11 Table 5 shows the comparison of mean and percentage coefficients of variation (cov %) of results obtained from Taguchi’s OA simulation and that of the PDF. Table 6 gives the comparison of the extreme values from the PDF and the worst case values using the Taguchi method.

caption.p: Histogram and individual frequency plots for identification of the probability distribution functions of the output parameters.
Probability distribution functions of the parameters identified from the results of Taguchi’s orthogonal array and chi-square goodness of fit in the satellite separation process.

tr.td: Body rate for the ongoing stage (°/s)
Relative distance of the separating bodies (m)
Relative velocity of the separating bodies (m/s)

fn.label: a
fn.p: Critical value of test statistics χ2 at 5% significance level.11

caption.p: Comparison of the parameters in the satellite separation process obtained from Taguchi simulation vis-’-vis probability distribution function (PDF).
Comparison of extreme values obtained from the probability distribution function (PDF) and worst case method of Taguchi.

tr.td: Body rate of the satellite, ω (deg/s)

sec.p: In Taguchi’s simulation, the input parameters for each run are fixed based on the OA. While conducting the fewer number of experiments as per Taguchi’s OA, there is no guarantee that all input parameters are specified in a normally distributed fashion. Hence, the output response need not obey normal distribution. However, one can find the optimum parameters to obtain the desired output response from the fewer number of experiments. The resultant velocity and the resultant displacement defined in Equations (19) and (20) are non-linear in nature. Hence, the distributions are different.

sec.title: 5. Reliability and safety assessments
sec.p: The limit state function for the loss/reduction in life of the satellite is the high body rate, which is more than the control capability of the system. Pa is the resultant body rate for different physical parameters within the set of tolerance. The critical body rate, Pcr is the set control capability limit in the satellite control system. The limit state function is
where X = {X1, X2, X3,…,Xn}T is a set of the continuous random variables. Loss of satellite/reduction in life occurs if Pcr ≤ Pa.
The probability of failure is expressed as:12

The probability of failure is estimated using Matlab tools. Reliability and safety assessments are made considering various control capability limits in the satellite (Pcr) and the results are presented in Table 7. It is clear that the higher control capability of the satellite yields a lower failure probability and higher reliability. It should be noted that the probability of failure is 0.0001 for the critical control capability of the satellite having 2.25 deg/s. This means that one failure can be expected in every 10,000 experiments. This is a reasonable assessment for satellite launch vehicles. The probability of failure can be minimized further by enhancing the critical control capability of the satellite. Figure 11 shows the ground test setup to measure the body rate of the separating satellite. The desirable body rate is less than 2 deg/s for nominal physical parameters.

caption.p: Reliability and safety assessments for various critical satellite control capabilities with probability distribution of the body rate for the set of physical parameters (in Table 1).

tr.th: Critical control capability of the satellite (deg/s) (Pcr)

caption.p: Ground test setup to measure the body rate of the separating satellite.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: Taguchi’s approach is followed for reliability and safety assessments in the satellite separation process of a typical launch vehicle. The Taguchi method is convenient for obtaining the PDF with less computational time. Hence, Taguchi’s OA-based simulations will be useful for reliability and safety assessments in the satellite separation process of multi-stage launch vehicles. The satellite body rate during the separating process is expressed in an empirical relation (Equation (21)) through response surface methodology, which will be of immense use for non-conformance management and to ensure the critical parameters for their compliance in the satellite separation process. For the specified physical parameters, the body rates of the satellite are found to be within the allowable limit as observed from the ground acceptance functional test. In the case that the body rate exceeds the satellite control limits, it is possible to control it by providing differential energy springs in the spring system assembly. This methodology can be utilized in aerospace applications related to the rigid body separation dynamics viz., large booster separation, core-stage separation, and ullage rocket separation. The present formulation works well for the low Earth orbit (LEO), highly elliptical orbit (HEO) and geo-stationary Earth orbit (GEO). Future work is directed towards extension of this approach to the separation dynamics of multiple satellites.

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: J Singaravelu is the Deputy Project Director (Product Assurance) of the Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle (GSLV Mk-III), which will be the most powerful launch vehicle of the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) to launch 4 tonne class satellites into geostationary transfer orbit (GTO). He is a Fellow of the Institute of Engineers, India. He is one of the Quality Management Systems (QMS) lead auditors of ISO-9000:2000. He obtained his BTech (Mechanical) from the National Institute of Technology, Calicut and his MTech from the Indian Institute of Technology, Madras. He joined the VSSC as a scientist in 1985 and worked as Quality Assurance Engineer of Aerospace Mechanisms, Stage Separation Systems, Heat Shield and Allied Space Ordinance systems for Launch Vehicles. His research interests are reliability based design optimization, Taguchi robust design, and statistical modeling.

Dr D Jeyakumar is the Deputy Project Director (Programme Management Office) of the RLV-TD, VSSC, Thiruvananthapuram. He obtained his MSc (1982) from the Madurai Kamaraj University, Madurai and his PhD (2008) from the Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University, Hyderabad. His research interests are dynamic characteristics of launch vehicle separation systems, trajectoryoptimization and sensitivity studies to improve the design parameters adopting Monte Carlo simulations, and multivariate concepts.

Dr B Nageswara Rao is the Head of the Structural Design and Analysis Division, Structural Analysis and Testing Group of Structural Engineering Entity, VSSC, Thiruvananthapuram. He is the research guide in the Faculty of Science, Engineering and Technology, University of Kerala. He is a reviewer for 20 international journals. He obtained his MSc (1975) and PhD (1982) from Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay. He joined the VSSC as a scientist in 1979. He has authored/co-authored 250 journal papers related to fracture mechanics, rocket motors/pressure vessels, non-linear beams/columns/plates, boundary layer flows, hot/cold working characteristics of materials, rigid body separation dynamics for space launch vehicles, superplastic forming, and hydro-forming deep drawing processes.
